Starting the day

Good morning, King of the Universe

As my body starts to realize it is a new day, I turn to you

As I sip from my cup and think about the day ahead, you remind me that you are always present

I praise you for a night of rest and restoration

And for the tasks that await  me at my computer

I thank you for the great duty of finding order in the code I create

As you created me in your image, I am also able to create

As Adam and Eve rebelled against you, I am also able to destroy

Create for good, create for evil

Destroy for good, destroy for evil

In this morningâ€™s glimpse of a new day, I turn to you

As I smell my coffee, and think about the challenges ahead of me, you remind me to be holy as you are

You invite me to use my hands to bring into existence programs that glorify you

To gift the world with code that proclaims your glory

May my code be creative, effective, hospitable

May my code prevent others of making mistakes, and keep me from dragging myself into sloppy solutions

May my code be a reflection of the love I have for you and for my neighbor

If I need to delete parts of my code, may I be wise enough to avoid wasting time coding things that wonâ€™t work, as a good steward should

If I forget specifics and leave some functions behind, may I remember that you never forget us

Enlighten me when I get stuck, not knowing what to do next

And join me in joy when my code runs smoothly

May my code be a reflection of who you want me to be

And as I finish my morning coffee and turn to the important work I need to do

Let not me be distracted by other things

Make my heart rest, knowing you will take care of my beloved ones and my coworkers

So I donâ€™t need to constantly check my messages and emails

Make my mind focused and disposed to find satisfaction in the coding and nothing more

So I donâ€™t get myself lost in the infinite timelines of social media and sensationalist news

Help me today, Lord

I will open my computer, and I will worship you with all I am

A creature whose core is programmed to love you through my programs

Amen.

hierarchy.lvl1: ðŸŸ¡ Grasping Big-O notation and complexity
ðŸŸ¡ Grasping Big-O notation and complexity

records.content:
Understanding computational complexity

Heavenly Father

Infinite

Perfect

Unfathomable

Not a drop of Jesus blood was wasted

Not a single strand of hair falls without your consent

You eternal nature is mysterious

And your days are more than an O(n!) algorithm.

Our O(n) days provides us with a sense of continuity

And a false impression that they will tend to the infinite

But our days are counted

In your eyes, the number of our days are like an O(1) algorithm

Short. Fast. Fleeting.

Teach us how to count our days as we wrestle counting the operations in our algorithms

As we seek to find an efficient solution to the problems we face in our discipline

Teach us that we are limited and Your creation has boundaries that should be respected

The algorithms we build require a great deal of power

And power is a scarce resource

We come to you for wisdom to grasp these concepts so we can build models that reflect our stewardship

We come to you for the right disposition as these concepts are not so intuitive

The Towers of Hanoi will teach us about the timeless of your nature

How long would take for 64 disks to be moved from one rod to another?

That is no time for you. But for us, thatâ€™s eternity.

God of order, how to sort things out?

What is the best way to put elements in the right place so our search may be O(log n)?

Why not taking the easiest path, and use the simpler algorithm?

May we have the resilience to learn the Quicksort algorithm and to be able to implement it with no struggles

May we dive into the many trees and their traversing, insertion and searching methods as we navigate our decisions in life.

Holy Lord, help us in our desire to count perfectly the number of operations in our algorithms

And lead us into humility, for the complexity of algorithms requires that we only look at the big picture, and not into the details

As we code our loops, or define a new data structure to hold our important data, may we donâ€™t get staggered in inefficient ways of modeling your world through our algorithms

Amem.

Welcome to a collection of prayers written for those who study, teach, and practice the craft of computing. I am Eric Araujo, professor of Computer Science at Calvin University and the curator of this collection. You are invited to explore, use, and contribute to these prayers as you seek to integrate your faith with your work in computer science.

In the discipline of Computer Science, we encounter profound questions about logic, creation, beauty, and human flourishing. These prayers are offered as a resource for students and professors who wish to integrate their faith with their intellectual work.

Whether youâ€™re starting a new semester, debugging stubborn code, wrestling with imposter syndrome, or preparing to teach a difficult concept, these prayers invite you to bring your whole selfâ€”mind, heart, and soulâ€”before God.

Explore our 

collection of Prayers, including:

A Prayer for the Beginning of a Semester - For professors and students as a new term begins

A Prayer Before Debugging - When the code will not run, and the error is hidden

A Prayer for the Student Facing Imposter Syndrome - When you feel you do not belong

A Prayer Before Teaching a Difficult Concept - For the professor preparing to explain what is hard
